MMS golfers compete in region tournaments

Blair Powers represented Mattoon Middle School at the Girls Sectional C at Lincoln Greens in Springfield. Blair shot a 98, allowing her to place fourth overall. Blair was accompanied by her mother, Sarah Powers, a MCUSD#2 teacher, as the girls coach representative.

In Paris at Eagle Ridge Golf Course, MMS had Madden Johnson, Will Pullen, and Parker Masse golfing in the Boys Sectional F. Madden Johnson shot an 83, and he placed fourth overall. Will Pullen shot an 88 and placed seventh. Parker Masse finished the day by shooting a personal best. Jordan Coleman accompanied the boys to Paris. Coleman is also a MCUSD#2 staff member, who agreed to be the Coaching Representative for the MMS boys this year.

IESA plans to mail medals to MMS for our athletes who placed in their respective sectionals. There is no State meet this year due to the pandemic. Either way - we want to congratulate our golfers and their leadership on representing MMS so well.

post_text: Angi Dallas, choir director, Mattoon High School, shared the following photos and information: We celebrated our choir and Green Wave Singers Seniors July 9, 2020. Thank you Drew Banks!
Drew Banks, owner of Lee’s Famous Recipe, wanted Mattoon High School seniors to graduate without having school lunch debt so he donated funds to MHS to eliminate the debt.
Banks, a Mattoon High School Class of 2009 alumnus, said when the closures were mandated by the state in March, he started offering free dinners at Lee Famous Recipe for students in kindergarten-12 grades for about two weeks. During the time Lee offered the free meals, Banks said they had customers offering donations to help support the program.
“I really appreciated them wanting to donate and give back to the community,” said Banks.
Banks decided to match their donations dollar for dollar. He donated money to the high school to pay the remainder of senior high school students’ lunch debt.
“These kids didn’t get a chance to walk in a graduation ceremony,” said Banks. “I felt the least I could do was let them graduate without lunch debt.”

Regional Office of Education #11
June 1 at 1:00 PM ·

Regional Office of Education 11 is pleased to recognize Mark Nelson with the 'Friends of Education' award.
Mark Nelson has dedicated the last 41 years to the Mattoon Community Unit School District 2 and has served as the Transportation Director for the last 15 years. In addition to his responsibilities for the school district, he has served as a certified school bus instructor for ROE #11 and has trained many of the bus drivers in our region. ROE #11 Transportation Coordinator Katie O'Dell said it best, "Mark's knowledge of school bus guidelines, regulations, law, safety, etc. has made him a valuable resource to our region for more than a decade. I hate to see him retire at the end of June, but I know he is looking forward to traveling (when it is safe) with his wife." Mark has made a positive impact on so many people in the community; as an administrator, driver, director, and instructor. Thanks for your service, Mark! #ROE11

Even following the announcement of the end of the 2019-2020 school year, Arland D. Williams Jr. Elementary School students have been hard at work continuing to earn their Run Club miles. Once a week, Mrs Kimbro and Mrs Haacke hold a remote Run Club where students walk/run/move up to one mile. Parents are asked to contact their child's assigned PE teacher and that mile gets added to their Run Club total. With the closing of school, Mrs Kimbro and Mrs Haacke felt like it was important to get these T-shirts delivered to their very hardworking, deserving students. Each student who earned a shirt was notified via email with a congratulatory certificate. Mrs Kimbro and Mrs Haacke are so proud of those who've earned their shirts, but also all their students who continue to stay active and strive for that goal. If families weren't able pick up the shirts, the shirts will be added to their child's student belongings bag.

LSC Communications donated coloring books and puzzle books to Mattoon Community Unit School District 2.
The books were placed in meal deliveries to our younger students Monday. Kris Maleske, community service director, thanked Brian Hinton of LSC Communications for their generosity.
“The books were an unexpected gift and they couldn’t have come at a better time with our students being at home,” said Maleske. “Students are looking for things to do right now. “LSC was very generous with their donation of books.”
Maleske reported that a volunteer who assists delivering the meals said the children she delivered meals to Monday were surprised by the books.
“I loved seeing the excited faces on our students and the pure joy that the coloring book brought to their day,” said Marsha Steele, teacher and volunteer, meal delivery.
